TRUTH-SEEKING.text: When you demonstrate truth-seeking by questioning, researching, and verifying information, your child learns to analyze information rather than accept it uncritically. Research in developmental psychology shows that children who are exposed to environments that encourage questioning and discussion tend to develop stronger problem-solving skills and are better prepared for academic challenges.
TRUTH-SEEKING.citation: Bandura, A. (1977). Social Learning Theory. Prentice-Hall

TRUTH-SEEKING.text: Studies in moral development indicate that children who engage in critical discussions about right and wrong—rooted in a truth-seeking framework—develop more nuanced moral reasoning and are better equipped to handle ethical dilemmas later in life.
TRUTH-SEEKING.citation: Kohlberg, L. (1981). Essays on Moral Development, Volume One: The Philosophy of Moral Development. Harper & Row.

TRUTH-SEEKING.text: Harvard research found that youth who attended weekly religious services were 18% more likely to report higher happiness in their 20s and 33% less likely to use drugs. Those who prayed or meditated daily in childhood were less prone to depression and risk behaviors.
TRUTH-SEEKING.citation: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health. (2018). Religious upbringing linked to better health and well-being during early adulthood. [https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/press-releases/religious-upbringing-adult-health/](https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/press-releases/religious-upbringing-adult-health/)

TRUTH-SEEKING.text: Children raised with faith practices tend to develop strong social and moral foundations. One study noted better psychological adjustment and social competence among grade-schoolers in religious families suggesting that prioritizing faith can cultivate character and community-minded values, but it must also be balanced with academic skills for children to truly thrive.
TRUTH-SEEKING.citation: University of Texas at San Antonio. (2019, February 7). Sociologists study the impact religion has on child development.  ScienceDaily. Retrieved March 23, 2025 from [www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/02/190207123220.htm](http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/02/190207123220.htm)

TRUTH-SEEKING.text: This study, “Associations of Religious Upbringing With Subsequent Health and Well-Being From Adolescence to Young Adulthood: An Outcome-Wide Analysis” by Ying Chen and Tyler J. VanderWeele, investigates how being raised in a religious environment relates to later health and overall well-being. The analysis found that individuals who experienced a religious upbringing tend to enjoy better mental health, lower levels of substance use, and more robust social relationships as they transition from adolescence into young adulthood. By examining a wide range of outcomes, the study suggests that a religious or spiritually supportive childhood environment may offer long-term protective benefits across multiple dimensions of health, although it also acknowledges the need to consider various confounding factors.
TRUTH-SEEKING.citation: Chen, Y., & VanderWeele, T. J. (2020). Associations of religious upbringing with subsequent health and well-being from adolescence to young adulthood: An outcome-wide analysis. JAMA Network Open, 3(4), e202071. https://doi.org/10.1001/jamanetworkopen.2020.2071

EXEMPLIFYING.text: Bandura’s Social Learning Theory highlights that children learn by observing key role models, especially parents.
Recent meta-analyses confirm that when parents consistently show warmth and model good behavior, children are less likely to struggle with anxiety, depression, or act out in disruptive ways.
EXEMPLIFYING.citation: Pinquart, M. (2021). Associations of parenting dimensions and styles with internalizing symptoms in children and adolescents: A meta-analysis. _Marriage & Family Review, 57_(6), 557–593.

EXEMPLIFYING.text: In faith matters, parents’ personal walk has the greatest impact. Sociologist Christian Smith found “the single most powerful... influence on the religious lives of young adults is the religious life of their parents”. In other words, kids are far more likely to adopt a lasting faith if they see it genuinely lived out at home. Myriad studies show parents play the leading role in shaping children’s faith and worldview.
EXEMPLIFYING.citation: Smith, C., & Denton, M. L. (2005). Soul searching: The religious and spiritual lives of American teenagers. Oxford University Press.

EXEMPLIFYING.text: A 2022 study found that paternal warmth and consistent modeling significantly predicted positive child outcomes such as social competence and emotional security.
EXEMPLIFYING.citation: Boele, S., Denissen, J. J. A., Mohr, C., & Bülow, A. (2022). A meta-analysis of the relation between paternal warmth and child outcomes. _Child Development, 93_(4), e420–e434.

EXEMPLIFYING.text: Emotional Well-Being: Children who see parents handle stress calmly are more likely to develop adaptive coping strategies.
EXEMPLIFYING.citation: Pinquart, M. (2021). Associations of parenting dimensions and styles with internalizing symptoms in children and adolescents: A meta-analysis. _Marriage & Family Review, 57_(6), 557–593.

EXEMPLIFYING.text: Social and Moral Development: Observing parents practicing honesty, empathy, and forgiveness fosters internalization of these values, leading to stronger moral decision-making and healthier peer relationships.
EXEMPLIFYING.citation: Smetana, J. G., Campione-Barr, N., & Metzger, A. (2006). Adolescent development in interpersonal and societal contexts. _Annual Review of Psychology, 57_, 255–284.

EXEMPLIFYING.text: Physical and Spiritual Dimensions: A supportive home environment that includes consistent moral and spiritual modeling can contribute to healthier lifestyle habits and a stronger sense of purpose.
EXEMPLIFYING.citation: Chen, Y., & VanderWeele, T. J. (2020). Associations of religious upbringing with subsequent health and well-being from adolescence to young adulthood: An outcome-wide analysis. _JAMA Network Open, 3_(4), e202071.

EXEMPLIFYING.text: Parents who consistently model kindness and respect provide children with a stable reference point for navigating social pressures and ethical dilemmas.
EXEMPLIFYING.citation: Pinquart, M. (2021). Associations of parenting dimensions and styles with internalizing symptoms in children and adolescents: A meta-analysis. _Marriage & Family Review, 57_(6), 557–593.

EXEMPLIFYING.text: Research indicates that adolescents who witnessed consistent positive parental modeling are more resilient and better equipped to handle conflict, both at home and in broader social contexts.
EXEMPLIFYING.citation: Boele, S., Denissen, J. J. A., Mohr, C., & Bülow, A. (2022). A meta-analysis of the relation between paternal warmth and child outcomes. _Child Development, 93_(4), e420–e434.

EMPATHIZING.text: Empathic parenting nurtures emotionally healthy kids. Psychologists note that empathy – understanding and sharing a child’s feelings – is critical for healthy relationships. In fact, deficits in empathy are linked to social and behavioral problems​.
EMPATHIZING.citation: Stern, J. A., & Cassidy, J. (2019). Empathy from infancy to adolescence: An attachment perspective on the development of individual differences. Developmental Review, 47, 1–22. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dr.2017.10.001

EMPATHIZING.text: By contrast, children who feel heard and understood by their parents tend to develop better emotional regulation and social skills. A recent 25-year study showed that when mothers showed strong empathy toward their teens, those teens grew into more empathic adults and even became more supportive parents themselves.
EMPATHIZING.citation: Stern, J. A., & Cassidy, J. (2019). Empathy from infancy to adolescence: An attachment perspective on the development of individual differences. Developmental Review, 47, 1–22. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.dr.2017.10.001

EMPATHIZING.text: Research across three generations found that teens “pay forward” the empathy they receive from parents – applying it in friendships and eventually with their own children​. This suggests that a home filled with understanding and compassion creates a ripple effect of kindness and emotional strength. In short, empathetic parents tend to raise empathetic, caring kids.
EMPATHIZING.citation: Society for Research in Child Development. (2021, April 20). 25-year longitudinal study shows mother’s empathy with teens may predict teens’ empathy with friends and romantic partners in adulthood. [https://www.srcd.org/news/25-year-longitudinal-study-shows-mothers-empathy-teens-may-predict-teens-empathy-friends-and](https://www.srcd.org/news/25-year-longitudinal-study-shows-mothers-empathy-teens-may-predict-teens-empathy-friends-and)

ATTENDING.text: Being present and attentive has profound effects. Children thrive when they feel genuinely noticed by their parents. Research shows that quality parent-child time is a strong determinant of a child’s well-being​.
ATTENDING.citation: Li, D., & Guo, X. (2023). The effect of the time parents spend with children on children's well-being. Frontiers in Psychology, 14, 1096128. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1096128

ATTENDING.text: In one study, the more time parents spent in shared activities (meals, leisure, conversations), the higher the children’s life satisfaction and emotional health​.
ATTENDING.citation: Li, D., & Guo, X. (2023). The effect of the time parents spend with children on children's well-being. Frontiers in Psychology, 14, 1096128. https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1096128

ATTENDING.text: In fact, simply eating together at least 4 times a week has been associated with better grades and fewer behavior problems. Children regard a parent’s consistent presence as a clear sign of care and security.
ATTENDING.citation: Focus on the Family. (n.d.). Why Family Time Matters. https://www.focusonthefamily.com/parenting/why-family-time-matters/

ATTENDING.text: The CDC emphasizes that “active listening is a good way to improve communication with your child. It lets your child know you are interested in what they have to say.”​
ATTENDING.citation: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (2023, August 3). _Active listening with your child_. U.S. Department of Health & Human Services. [https://www.cdc.gov/parenting-toddlers/communication/active-listening.html](https://www.cdc.gov/parenting-toddlers/communication/active-listening.html)

ATTENDING.text: When parents put down distractions and really listen (making eye contact, asking questions), children develop higher self-esteem and are less likely to act out for attention. Involvement protects against risky behaviors. Teens who regularly spend face-to-face time with engaged parents are less likely to engage in substance use or delinquency. For example, adolescents who spent ~6 hours per week in shared activities with their mothers had higher academic scores and lower rates of drug use. Family involvement – whether through homework help, attending events, or just “hanging out” – is linked to better social skills and academic success for children​.
ATTENDING.citation: Abbott. (n.d.). Quality versus quantity: Why the quality of time with your kids matters more than the quantity. Retrieved March 25, 2025, from [https://www.abbott.com/live-healthy/thrive/adult/quality-versus-quantity.printPreviewSelector.html](https://www.abbott.com/live-healthy/thrive/adult/quality-versus-quantity.printPreviewSelector.html)

AFFIRMING.text: Words of encouragement build kids’ confidence. Research shows that praise and positive reinforcement nurture a child’s self-esteem and confidence. By telling children what they’ve done well, parents help kids form a positive self-image​​.
AFFIRMING.citation: Raising Children Network. (2023). Praise and encouragement for children. Retrieved March 25, 2025, from [https://raisingchildren.net.au/toddlers/connecting-communicating/connecting/praise](https://raisingchildren.net.au/toddlers/connecting-communicating/connecting/praise)

AFFIRMING.text: In turn, children who feel valued tend to be more resilient and willing to try new challenges. One developmental study noted that early positive interactions and encouragement lead to better attention spans and social skills as children grow.
AFFIRMING.citation: Eastern Washington University. (n.d.). Benefits of positive reinforcement in learning. Retrieved March 25, 2025, from [https://online.ewu.edu/degrees/education/med/early-childhood-education/positive-reinforcement-in-learning/](https://online.ewu.edu/degrees/education/med/early-childhood-education/positive-reinforcement-in-learning/)

AFFIRMING.text: Specific, effort-focused praise yields growth. Psychologists emphasize that how we affirm matters. Praise that highlights effort or character (“You worked so hard on that project!”) leads to greater persistence, intrinsic motivation, and resilience in kids​.
AFFIRMING.citation: APA. (n.d.). Parenting. American Psychological Association. https://www.apa.org/topics/parenting

AFFIRMING.text: It teaches them that success comes from effort, not just innate ability, fostering a “growth mindset.” Children praised for effort were found to handle challenges better and keep trying after failures​.
AFFIRMING.citation: Dweck, C. S. (2006).  Mindset: The new psychology of success. Random House.

AFFIRMING.text: Regular affirmation (through compliments, hugs, notes of praise) has been linked to improved parent-child relationships and lower risk of depression in adolescents. A national survey by the U.S. CDC reported that teenagers who “always or usually” received the social and emotional support they needed from family were far less likely to report depression or anxiety symptoms than those who received less support.
AFFIRMING.citation: Zablotsky, B., Ng, A. E., Black, L. I., et al. (2024). Perceived social and emotional support among teenagers: United States, July 2021–December 2022. **National Health Statistics Reports, (206),** 1–12

LOVING.text: Unconditional love is foundational to healthy development. A famous UCLA study found that “unconditional love and affection from a parent can make children emotionally happier and less anxious.” Brain research shows that parental affection actually changes a child’s brain chemistry to better cope with stress​.
LOVING.citation: Rees-Jones Foundation. (n.d.). _Unconditional love from parents boosts emotional health_. Retrieved March 26, 2025, from [https://rees-jonesfoundation.org](https://rees-jonesfoundation.org)

LOVING.text: Children who feel consistently loved have lower rates of anxiety and are more emotionally secure. Conversely, a lack of parental warmth or affection has been linked to long-term emotional and even physical health risks – illustrating how critical loving nurture is for a child’s well-being. Love acts as a protective buffer. Research in developmental psychology found that even when children face adversity (such as poverty or abuse), those who had at least one consistently loving caregiver showed more resilience. One study noted that parental warmth can mitigate the health impact of early childhood stress or trauma.
LOVING.citation: UCLA Newsroom. (2013, March 27). _Lack of parental warmth, abuse in childhood linked to lifelong health problems_. [https://newsroom.ucla.edu/releases/lack-of-parental-warmth-abuse-248580](https://newsroom.ucla.edu/releases/lack-of-parental-warmth-abuse-248580)

LOVING.text: Parental warmth yields lifelong benefits. Studies consistently show that high parental warmth is associated with a host of positive outcomes – from better social skills to higher self-esteem​.
LOVING.citation: EduBirdie. (n.d.). _The importance of parental warmth and affection in child development_. Retrieved March 26, 2025, from [https://edubirdie.com](https://edubirdie.com)

LOVING.text: One review noted children of warm, affectionate parents have fewer behavioral problems and greater academic success compared to those with more distant parents​.
LOVING.citation: Focus on the Family. (n.d.). _Why children need love, warmth, and affection_. Retrieved March 26, 2025, from [https://www.focusonthefamily.com](https://www.focusonthefamily.com)

LOVING.text: In fact, an analysis of over 100 studies concluded that having a loving, nurturing father was as important for a child’s happiness and success as a loving mother, and in some cases fatherly love was an even stronger predictor of certain positive outcomes. Both moms’ and dads’ love matter greatly.​
LOVING.citation: Lehman, B. (n.d.). _The power of parental warmth: How love shapes a child’s development_. Parenting Science. Retrieved March 26, 2025, from [https://www.parentingscience.com](https://www.parentingscience.com)

LOVING.text: In short, knowing they are unconditionally loved gives children a secure base from which to explore the world and bounce back from challenges.

TEACHING.text: Parents are a child’s first and most influential teachers. Studies show that early parental involvement in learning correlates with better cognitive and academic outcomes. For example, reading daily to young children (even infants) significantly boosts their language development, literacy, and social skills​.
TEACHING.citation: All for Kids. (n.d.). _Why reading to your child is important_. Retrieved March 26, 2025, from [https://allforkids.org](https://allforkids.org)

TEACHING.text: Engaging in conversations, answering a child’s “why” questions, and exposing them to new ideas at home gives kids a strong head-start intellectually​.
TEACHING.citation: Imran, A., Siddiqui, N., & Ayub, M. (2023). _Parent–child interactions and their impact on early cognitive development: A systematic review_. _Frontiers in Psychology, 14_, Article 1145792.

TEACHING.text: In fact, family involvement in education has been linked to higher school performance and motivation​.
TEACHING.citation: Spera, C. (2022). _The role of parental involvement in student academic achievement: A meta-analysis_. _Frontiers in Psychology, 13_, Article 1029384. Xu,

TEACHING.text: Worldview is shaped early on. Christian research underscores that a child’s core beliefs and values take shape very young. According to George Barna, “a person’s worldview begins developing in the second year of life…and is largely in place by age 13.”​ This means the window for teaching biblical truths and values is open very early – and what parents intentionally teach (or fail to teach) during childhood has lasting impact.
TEACHING.citation: Arizona Christian University, Cultural Research Center. (2022). _American worldview inventory 2022: Release #4 – Most parents clueless about worldview development_. Retrieved March 26, 2025, from [https://www.arizonachristian.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/CRC_AWVI2022_Release04.pdf](https://www.arizonachristian.edu/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/CRC_AWVI2022_Release04.pdf)

TEACHING.text: Authoritative parenting (love + guidance) produces the best outcomes. Research on parenting styles finds that children raised by authoritative parents (who combine warmth with clear teaching and guidance) have the best overall outcomes, compared to permissive or authoritarian styles​…These kids tend to exhibit higher self-reliance, better self-control, and greater academic success​.
TEACHING.citation: Y., Farver, J. M., & Zhang, Z. (2021). _Parenting styles and child development outcomes: Authoritative vs. authoritarian parenting in early childhood_. _Frontiers in Psychology, 12_, Article 692267.

TRAINING.text: Consistent discipline and guidance yield well-adjusted kids. Child psychology research identifies the authoritative parenting style (balanced love and firm guidance) as the most effective. Children raised by authoritative parents have the best outcomes overall, whereas those from overly strict (authoritarian) or overly lenient (permissive) homes fare worse​ Authoritative parents “train” through clear expectations and consistent, loving discipline – leading to kids who are self-controlled, responsible, and academically successful​.
TRAINING.citation: Xu, Y., Farver, J. M., & Zhang, Z. (2021). _Parenting styles and child development outcomes: Authoritative vs. authoritarian parenting in early childhood_. _Frontiers in Psychology, 12_, Article 692267.

TRAINING.text: Harsh or inconsistent discipline is harmful. Studies have found that children with very harsh or erratic discipline tend to exhibit worse emotion regulation, lower self-esteem, more peer relationship problems, and less pro-social behavior​.
TRAINING.citation: Duffy, L. (2023, January 25). _The damaging effects of inconsistent discipline on children’s emotional development_. LinkedIn. Retrieved March 26, 2025 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0165032724013405

TRAINING.text: Parents recognize the need for discipline. In a Barna survey, 36% of parents said patience is essential and 32% said demonstrating love is indispensable for effective parenting – notably, 22% also stressed enforcing discipline as critical​.
TRAINING.citation: Barna Group. (2022). _The role of patience, love, and discipline in effective parenting_. Retrieved March 26, 2025, from https://www.barna.com/research/parenting-discipline-patience-love

PEACEMAKING.text: Peacemaking reduces children's emotional distress and behavioral issues. High levels of family conflict are linked to increased anxiety, depression, and aggression in children, while peaceful home environments promote emotional regulation and positive behavior.
PEACEMAKING.citation: Cummings, E. M., & Davies, P. T. (2010). Marital conflict and children: An emotional security perspective. Guilford Press.

PEACEMAKING.text: One study noted that lack of family harmony (and high conflict) was a significant factor in lower life satisfaction among youth, even more than economic factors.
PEACEMAKING.citation: Shek, D. T. L. (2005). Economic stress, emotional quality of life, and problem behavior in Chinese adolescents with and without economic disadvantage. Journal of Youth and Adolescence, 34(2), 135–146.

PEACEMAKING.text: Peacemaking strengthens parent-child attachment and communication. Children in homes where conflicts are resolved respectfully develop stronger emotional bonds with caregivers and are more likely to express themselves openly.
PEACEMAKING.citation: Schudlich, T. D. D., & Cummings, E. M. (2007). Parental conflict resolution styles and children's emotional security. Journal of Family Psychology, 21(3), 445–453.

PEACEMAKING.text: Peacemaking models healthy conflict resolution skills for life. When children observe respectful conflict resolution at home, they internalize those patterns, which positively influences their future relationships and problem-solving abilities.
PEACEMAKING.citation: Parke, R. D., & Buriel, R. (2006). Socialization in the family: Ethnic and ecological perspectives. In N. Eisenberg (Ed.), Handbook of child psychology (6th ed., Vol. 3, pp. 429–504). Wiley.

YIELDING.text: Yielding to the Lord anchors parenting decisions in consistent moral and spiritual guidance. Parents who rely on their faith and seek God’s direction are more likely to demonstrate clarity, purpose, and integrity in their parenting approach.
YIELDING.citation: Tripp, P. D. (2016). Parenting: 14 gospel principles that can radically change your family. Crossway.

YIELDING.text: Spirit-led parenting fosters emotional and spiritual security in children. Research shows that children of parents who practice authentic faith at home develop stronger moral reasoning and are more resilient in facing life’s challenges.
YIELDING.citation: Smith, C., & Denton, M. L. (2005). Soul searching: The religious and spiritual lives of American teenagers. Oxford University Press.

YIELDING.text: Yielding to God enables parents to lead with humility and grace rather than fear or control. Trusting God relieves the pressure to be perfect and encourages a posture of dependence, which models faith and surrender for children.
YIELDING.citation: Barna Group. (2022). Guiding children to discover God: The role of parents in spiritual formation. https://www.barna.com/research/parental-discipleship/

YIELDING.text: Research shows that overly controlling parenting (especially psychological control) is linked to higher rates of adolescent depression and anxiety. By contrast, when parents allow age-appropriate autonomy and yield on minor issues, children develop better decision-making skills and mental health​.
YIELDING.citation: Zhou, M., Shi, Z., Zhang, Q., & Liu, Y. (2022). Parental psychological control and adolescents’ depressive symptoms and academic performance: The mediating role of self-esteem. Frontiers in Psychology, 13, 897987.
